verses.text: The word of the Lord came unto Meqa'abyan in the days of his old age, saying: 'Speak to the children of Israel and say unto them: "Hearken, O Israel, to the statutes of the Lord and observe His judgements."
'For the Lord is a great King over all the earth, and there is none like Him in power or in wisdom.'
'He hath chosen you to be His people from among all the nations, and He hath given you His law that ye may walk in it and live.'
'But behold, I see that your hearts are turned away from Me, and ye have followed the vanities of the Gentiles.'
'Ye have worshipped the work of your own hands, and ye have forgotten the God who brought you out of the land of Egypt.'
And Meqa'abyan went forth and stood in the gate of the city, and he cried with a loud voice to all the people.
And he said: 'O ye children of Jacob, why do ye provoke the Lord to anger with your idols? Do ye not know that He is a consuming fire?'
'Return therefore to the Lord, and He will have mercy on you; and put away the strange gods from your midst, that ye may be saved from the wrath to come.'
Then the people were moved by the words of Meqa'abyan, and they began to weep and to lament for their sins.
And they said: 'Truly we have sinned against the Lord, and we have done evil in His sight; but now we desire to return to Him with all our heart.'
And they took their idols of silver and gold and cast them into the fire, and they destroyed the high places which they had built.
And they fasted forty days and forty nights, and they wore sackcloth and ashes upon their heads.
And the Lord saw their repentance, and He was entreated of them; and He sent a prophet named Zadok to comfort them.
And Zadok said: 'Thus saith the Lord: Because ye have humbled yourselves before Me, I will not bring the evil upon you in your days; but I will bless you and multiply you in the land.'
Now there was a man in the city named Barok, and he was a man of great wealth and pride.
And he did not join with the people in their repentance, but he mocked them, saying: 'Why do ye afflict yourselves for a God who doth not see or hear?'
And he continued to worship his idols in secret, and he encouraged others to do the same.
And Meqa'abyan went to the house of Barok and said to him: 'O man of a hardened heart, why dost thou tempt the Lord? Behold, the day of judgement is at hand.'
But Barok laughed and said: 'I fear not thy words, for I have my riches and my gods to protect me.'
Then Meqa'abyan said: 'Thy riches shall perish with thee, and thy gods shall not be able to deliver thee from the hand of the Almighty.'
And it came to pass that a great fire broke out in the house of Barok, and all his wealth was consumed in one hour.
And Barok himself was struck with a leprosy, so that his flesh fell from his bones, and he died in great misery.
And all the people saw the judgement of God upon Barok, and they feared the Lord more than before.
And they said: 'Truly the Lord is a righteous Judge, and He requiteth every man according to his works.'
After these things, Meqa'abyan had a vision of the end of the world and the final judgement of all flesh.
And he saw a great throne set in the heavens, and One sat upon it whose face was like the sun in its strength.
And thousands of thousands of angels stood before Him, and the books were opened before Him.
And he saw the souls of all men brought before the throne, and they were judged according to that which was written in the books.
And the righteous were set on the right hand, and they were given robes of light and crowns of glory.
But the wicked were set on the left hand, and they were cast into a lake of fire and brimstone, where there is weeping and gnashing of teeth.
And Meqa'abyan saw the state of the righteous in the world to come, and he saw that they dwelt in a city of gold and precious stones.
And there was no need of the sun or the moon to give light, for the glory of the Lord was the light thereof.
And there was no more death, neither sorrow nor crying, for the former things were passed away.
And he saw the tree of life in the midst of the city, and its fruit was for the healing of the nations.
And one of the angels said to him: 'Meqa'abyan, this is the inheritance of those who love God and keep His commandments.'
And when Meqa'abyan awoke from his vision, he was filled with joy and wonder.
And he called the people together and told them all that he had seen and heard.
And he said: 'My children, the time is short, and the world passeth away; but the word of our God abideth for ever.'
'Therefore, set your hearts on the things that are above, and do not love the world or the things that are in the world.'
'For the eye hath not seen, nor the ear heard, the things which God hath prepared for them that wait for Him.'
Now after these things, Meqa'abyan fell asleep with his fathers, and he was buried in the city of his fathers.
And all Israel made a great mourning for him, for he was the last of the righteous kings who had saved the land from the idols.
And after his death, there was no more any king in Israel who was like him in faith and in the fear of the Lord.
But the people continued to walk in the way of the Lord for many years, for they remembered the words and the visions of Meqa'abyan.
Blessed is the man who walketh in the law of the Lord and whose delight is in His commandments.
He shall be like a tree planted by the rivers of water, that bringeth forth its fruit in its season.
But the ungodly are not so, but are like the chaff which the wind driveth away.
Therefore the ungodly shall not stand in the judgement, nor sinners in the assembly of the righteous.
For the Lord knoweth the way of the righteous, but the way of the ungodly shall perish.
Now the rest of the words of the three books of Meqa'abyan, and their prophecies and their wonders, are they not written in the books of the faithful?
And may the blessing of the Lord be upon all who read them and observe the words of the law.
Glory be to the Father, and to the Son, and to the Holy Spirit, now and for ever, and throughout all ages. Amen and Amen.
